importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the most recent update on the ongoing flooding disaster, providing context for the current status of the humanitarian crisis and emergency response efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timing of the flooding—occurring last week—highlights a recent natural disaster that has triggered immediate and sustained emergency responses across multiple Mexican states.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died due to heavy rains and flooding in five Mexican states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, confirmed 65 people are still missing.
Veracruz reported 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro 1.
43 people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Thousands of military personnel from the Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to assist in rescue and relief operations.
Over 100,000 homes have been affected, with some structures reportedly 'practically disappeared' due to flooding and landslides.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which led to rapid river rises.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain, respectively.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply for around 263,000 affected users.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no prior meteorological warnings indicating such extreme rainfall.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused severe flooding and landslides across five Mexican states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The hardest-hit states were Veracruz, Hidalgo, and Puebla, with Veracruz reporting the highest number of fatalities and extreme rainfall. The National Civil Protection Coordination and military forces, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have launched a large-scale emergency response, delivering food, water, and aid to isolated areas. Over 100,000 homes have been affected, with some structures destroyed. Despite extensive damage, nearly 80% of the electricity supply has been restored. President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua emphasized the absence of prior meteorological warnings, raising questions about Mexico’s early warning systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
